content: The Act titled "Combating Opioid Abuse for Care in Hospitals Act of 2018" or the "COACH Act of 2018" aims to provide guidance on pain management and opioid use disorder prevention for hospitals receiving Medicare Part A payments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must develop guidance for hospitals receiving Medicare Part A payments on pain management and opioid use disorder prevention by January 1, 2019, consulting with relevant stakeholders. The guidance for hospitals on pain management and opioid use disorder prevention will include best practices for screening, education initiatives, and resources for at-risk individuals. The curr_chunk discusses best practices for hospitals to educate practitioners on pain management and substance use disorders, including adverse effects of opioids, non-opioid treatments, monitoring programs, and naloxone prescribing. It also mentions making individuals aware of opioid risks and a notification template developed by the Secretary. The curr_chunk discusses a notification template developed by the Secretary for individuals prescribed opioids, explaining risks, side effects, non-opioid alternatives, and encouraging discussions with healthcare providers. The curr_chunk outlines requirements for a notification template for individuals prescribed opioids, including acknowledgment methods, language options, and additional information as determined appropriate by the Secretary. It also mentions best practices for hospitals to track opioid prescribing trends by practitioners. The curr_chunk provides guidance on opioid prescribing practices for practitioners, including monitoring medical records, reducing long-term prescriptions, and identifying potential over-prescribers. It also includes additional information determined appropriate by the Secretary, such as resources from the Opioid Safety Initiative and Opioid Overdose Prevention Toolkit. The curr_chunk focuses on the review of quality measures related to opioids and opioid use disorder treatments in federal health care programs. The Secretary will establish a technical expert panel to review quality measures for opioids and opioid use disorders in federal health care programs. The technical expert panel will review quality measures related to opioids and opioid use disorders, identify gaps in measurement areas, prioritize measure development, and make recommendations to the Secretary for improving care and treatment. The Secretary will consider recommendations for revisions and development of new measures related to opioids and opioid use disorder for inclusion in various healthcare programs. The Secretary will prioritize gaps in quality measures for development, including opioid measures in alternative payment models and quality reporting requirements for hospitals. The Social Security Act is amended to include an expedited endorsement process for opioid measures, prioritizing the endorsement of measures related to opioids and opioid use disorders. Technical expert panel established to reduce opioid use in surgical settings and collect data on perioperative opioid use. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will convene a technical expert panel to provide recommendations on reducing opioid use in surgical settings, focusing on limiting patient exposure to opioids and identifying at-risk patients pre-operation. Shared decision making with patients will also be emphasized. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will convene a technical expert panel to provide recommendations on reducing opioid use in surgical settings, focusing on limiting patient exposure to opioids and identifying at-risk patients pre-operation. Recommendations include shared decision making on pain management, education on safe opioid use, prevention of misuse and abuse after discharge, and developing a clinical algorithm for treating at-risk patients. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to Congress containing recommendations for pain management protocols that limit opioid use in surgical settings and an action plan for broader implementation. Additionally, a report on data collection regarding perioperative opioid use will be provided, including diagnosis-related group codes with the highest surgery volume. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide data on opioid use following surgeries, including surgical volumes, prescribing patterns, perioperative days of therapy, and post-discharge prescriptions. This information aims to limit opioid consumption in surgical settings. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide data on perioperative opioid use, including quantity consumed, refills, regional anesthesia practices, naloxone reversal, post-operative respiratory failure, storage, disposal information, and recommendations for improving data collection. SEC. 5. REQUIRING POSTING AND UPDATING OPIOID PRESCRIBING GUIDANCE FOR MEDICARE BENEFICIARIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must post all guidance related to opioid prescribing for Medicare beneficiaries on the CMS website within 180 days of this Act. The guidance will be updated periodically in consultation with specified entities. The Secretary must post opioid prescribing guidance for Medicare beneficiaries on the CMS website within 180 days, consulting with specified entities including medical organizations, providers, health care consumers, and other appropriate entities. The House of Representatives passed the document on June 19, 2018, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
